Quote: It became easy to overlook the opportunities to make something positive of camp life, opportunities which really did exist. People forget that often it is just such an exceptionally difficult external situation which gives man the opportunity to grow spiritually beyond himself.
Author: Victor Frankl

Quote: Emotion, which is suffering, ceases to be suffering as soon as we form a clear and precise picture of it.
Author: Victor Frankl

Quote: The attempt to develop a sense of humor and to see things in a humorous light is some kind of trick learned while mastering the art of living.
Author: Victor Frankl

Quote: Happiness is not something you postpone for the future; it is something you design for the present.
Author: Zig Ziglar

Quote: Readily agreeing with negative feedback is just another form of defensiveness.
Author: Zach Stanford

Quote: Beware of isolating when conversing in a group. All it takes is a simple, yet equally distributed, glance to each person present.
Author: Zach Stanford

Quote: I find it exciting when I don't understand a generally well-accepted quote for it reminds me that I have yet many life lessons to learn and experience.
Author: Zach Stanford

Quote: The best teacher is the one who is able to take a simple subject and create a profound classroom discussion by asking deeply thought-provoking questions.
Author: Zach Stanford

Quote: Being realistic is the most commonly traveled road to mediocrity.
Author: Will Smith

Quote: Your job should not be the most important thing in your life. The key to a successful and happy life is balance. Your job is part of that balance, but only a part. Make time for your family and friends - and for yourself.
Author: Steve Burke

Quote: Trusting your intuition means tuning in as deeply as you can to the energy you feel, following that energy moment to moment, trusting that it will lead you where you want to go and bring you everything you desire.
Author: Shakti Gawain

Quote: For some people, the longing to be popular far outweighs the longing to be respected, and their social media accounts can verify this.
Author: Paul Hiebert

Quote: The best way to have a good idea is to have a lot of ideas.
Author: Linus Pauling

Quote: If you are drawn to an enlightened teacher, it is because there is already enough presence in you to recognize presence in another. Egos, however, are drawn to false teachers. Darkness cannot recognize light. Only light can recognize light.
Author: Eckhart Tolle

Quote: The homemaker has the ultimate career. All other careers exist for one purpose -- and that is to support the ultimate career.
Author: C.S. Lewis

Quote: I can't imagine a man really enjoying a book and reading it only once.
Author: C.S. Lewis

Quote: Meditation is used to let go of sensual desires, anger, laziness, restlessness, boredom, and doubt. Once these are let go, the mind is concentrated, and the world is clearer than ever.
Author: Buddhist Podcast

Quote: The greatest good you can do for another is not just to share your riches, but to reveal to him his own.
Author: Benjamin Disraeli

Quote: Find a job you love and you love and you'll never work a day in your life.
Author: Clayton Christensen
Source: How Will You Measure Your Life?

Quote: Indeed, while experiences and information can be good teachers, there are many times in life where we simply cannot afford to learn on the job. You don't want to have to go through multiple marriages to learn how to be a good spouse. Or wait until your last child has grown to master parenthood. That is why theory can be so valuable: it can explain what will happen, even before you experience it.
Author: Clayton Christensen
Source: How Will You Measure Your Life?

Quote: Every man I meet is my superior in some way. In that, I learn of him.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: People who can put themselves in the place of other people, who can understand the workings of their minds, need never worry about what the future has in store for them.
Author: Owen D. Young
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: Many people fail to make a favorable impression because they don't listen attentively. They have been so much concerned with what they are going to say next that they do not keep their ears open. Very important people have told me that they prefer good listeners to good talkers, but the ability to listen seems rarer than almost any other good trait.
Author: Issac F. Marcosson
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.
Author: Dale Carnegie
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: And so I had him thinking of me as a good conversationalist when, in reality, I had been merely a good listener and had encouraged him to talk.
Author: Dale Carnegie
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: A person's name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language.
Author: Dale Carnegie
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: Criticism is futile because it puts a person on the defensive and usually makes him strive to justify himself. Criticism is dangerous, because it wounds a person's precious pride, hurts his sense of importance, and arouses resentment.
Author: Dale Carnegie
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: A man without a smiling face must not open shop.
Author: Chinese Proverb
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: I have yet to find a person, however great or exalted his station, who did not do better work and put forth greater effort under a spirit of approval than he would ever do under a spirit of criticism.
Author: Charles Schwab
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: Hatred is never ended by hatred, but by love.
Author: Buddha
Source: How to Win Friends & Influence People

Quote: A sharp saw always cuts faster and better, and we must never be too busy to sharpen ours.
Author: Stephen R. Covey

Quote: He did each thing as if he did nothing else.
Author: Charles Dickens

Quote: A Level 5 leader is an individual who blends extreme personal humility with intense professional will.
Author: Jim Collins

Quote: People and companies that suffer from the curse of competence rarely become great.
Author: Jim Collins

Quote: I've come to believe that any serious attempt to cultivate the moral and spiritual dimensions of life will begin to generate and nourish growing suspicions of something more, that something more to which religious faith is both a response and a call.
Author: Thomas V. Morris

Quote: I am a Christian because the deep resources of Christian theology resonate with and make sense of both the contours of my experience and the lineaments of my thoughts.
Author: Thomas V. Morris

Quote: It is clear to me that it is not just discrete and dramatic, extraordinary experiences of a limited duration and a memorable nature that function in one's coming to have and then both maintaining and maturing in a religious world view--but it seems to me that the job has been done in my own life primarily by a lot of little experiences, insights, intuitions, feelings, adumbrations, and convictions I have sensed forming within myself.
Author: Thomas V. Morris

Quote: Men must measure their esteem of each other by what each is, and not by what each has.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Say to them that threaten your independence: O father, O mother, O wife, O friend, I have lived with you after your appearances hitherto. Henceforward I am the truth's. Be it known unto you that henceforward I obey no law less than the eternal law. I will have no covenants but proximities. I shall endeavor to nourish my parents to support my family, to be the chaste husband of one wife,--but these relations I must fill after a new and unprecedented way. I appeal from your customs. I must be myself. I cannot break myself any longer for you. If you can love me for what I am, we shall be the happier. If you cannot, I will still seek to deserve that you should. I will not hide my tastes or aversions. I will so trust that what is deep is holy, that I will do strongly before the sun and moon whatever inly rejoices me, and the heart appoints. If you are noble, I will love you; if you are not, I will not hurt you and myself by hypocritical attentions. I fyou are true, but not in the same truth with me, cleave to your companions; I will seek my own. I do this not selfishly, but humbly and truly. It is alike your interest, and mine, and all men's however long we have dwelt in lies, to live in truth. Does this sound harsh today? You will soon love what is dictated by your nature as well as mine, and, if we follow the truth, it will bring us out safe at last.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Good and bad are but names very readily transferable to that or this; the only right is what is after my constitution, the only wrong what is against it.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Whoso would be a man must be a nonconformist. Nothing is at last sacred but the integrity of your own mind.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Trust thyself; every heart vibrates to that iron string.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: I do then with my friends as I do with my books. I would have them where I can find them, but I seldom use them. We must have society on our own terms, and admit or exclude it on the slightest cause. I cannot afford to speak too much with my friend. If he is great, he makes me so great that I cannot descend to converse.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: It is foolish to be afraid of making our ties too spiritual, as if so we could lose any genuine love.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: The higher the style we demand of friendship, of course the less easy to establish it with flesh and blood. We walk alone in the world. Friends, such as we desire, are dreams and fables.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Wait, and thy heart shall speak. Wait until the necessary and everlasting overpowers you, until day and night avail themselves of your lips. The only reward of virtue is virtue; the only way to have a friend is to be one. You shall not come nearer a man by getting into his house. If unlike, his soul only flees the faster from you, and you shall never catch a true glance of his eye.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Friendship demands a religious treatment. We talk of choosing our friends, but friends are self-elected. Reverence is a great part of it. Treat your friend as a spectacle.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Let this friendship be an alliance of two large, formidable natures, mutually beheld, mutually feared, before yet they recognize the deep identity which beneath these disparities unites them.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: We are to dignify our friend the daily needs and offices of man's life, and embellish it by courage, wisdom, and unity. Our friendship should never fall into something usual and settled, but should be alert and inventive, and add rhyme and reason to what was drudgery.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: I hate the prostitution of the name of friendship to signify modish and worldly alliances.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Let us approach our friend with an audacious trust in the truth of his heart, in the breadth, impossible to be overturned, of his foundations.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Almost all people descend to meet. All association must be a compromise, and, what is worst, the very flower and aroma of the flower of each of the beautiful natures disappears as they approach each other. What a perpetual disappointment is actual society, even of the virtuous and gifted!
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
Author: Aristotle

Quote: If you have a 10-horsepower motor and you subject it to a 12-horsepower load, it will burn out. But when you have a human body that is the equivalent of a 10-horsepower motor and you subject it to a 12-horsepower load, it eventually becomes a 12-horsepower motor.
Author: Lawrence Golding

Quote: Until we can receive with an open heart, we are never really giving with an open heart. When we attach judgment to receiving help, we knowingly or unknowingly attach judgment to giving help.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: There's a crack in everything. That's how the light gets in.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: We either own our stories (even the messy ones), or we stand outside of them--denying our vulnerabilities and imperfections, orphaning the parts of us that don't fit in with who/what we think we're supposed to be, and hustling for other people's approval of our worthiness.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: Vulnerability is not oversharing or purging; rather, it is sharing our feelings and experiences with people who have earned the right to hear them.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: Vulnerability is the birthplace of love, belonging, joy, courage, empathy, and creativity. It is the source of hope, empathy, accountability, and authenticity. If we want greater clarity in our purpose or deeper and more meaningful spiritual lives, vulnerability is the path.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: Connection is why we're here. We are hardwired to connect with others, it's what gives purpose and meaning to our lives, and without it there is suffering.
Author: Brene Brown

Quote: Well, when one has no one, nowhere else one can go! Do you understand, sir, do you understand what it means when you have absolutely nowhere to turn? For every man must have somewhere to go.
Author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

Quote: The more men have to lose, the less willing are they to venture. The rich are in general slaves to fear.
Author: Thomas Paine

Quote: Of more worth is one honest man to society and in the sight of God, than all the crowned ruffians that ever lived.
Author: Thomas Paine

Quote: It was about this time I conceived the bold an arduous project of arriving at moral perfection. I wished to live without committing any fault at any time; I would conquer all that either natural inclination, custom, or company might lead me into.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: The strong calm man is always loved and revered. That exquisite poise of character which we call serenity is the fruitage of the soul. It is precious as wisdom, more to be desired than gold--yea, than even fine gold.
Author: James Allen

Quote: The greatest achievement was at first and for a time a dream. The oak sleeps in the acorn; the bird waits in the egg; and in the highest vision of the soul a waking angel stirs. Dreams are the seedlings of realities.
Author: James Allen

Quote: He who has conquered doubt and fear has conquered failure.
Author: James Allen

Quote: Thought and character are one, and as character can only manifest and discover itself through environment and circumstance, the outer conditions of a person's life will always be found to be harmoniously related to his inner state.
Author: James Allen

Quote: A noble and Godlike character is not a thing of favor or chance, but is the natural result of continued effort in right thinking, the effect of long-cherished association with Godlike thoughts.
Author: James Allen

Quote: When one of the nicest people on the planet is also a very tough businessman, that's a rare and effective combination.
Author: William Novak

Quote: Even when Ralph was angry, he never raised his voice. And in the rare cases when he did show anger, it seemed more like disappointment.
Author: William Novak

Quote:
10 powerful phrases for positive people:
 1. I'm wrong. 
 2. I'm sorry.
 3. You can do it.
 4. I believe in you.
 5. I'm proud of you.
 6. Thank you.
 7. I need you.
 8. I trust you.
 9. I respect you.
 10. I love you.
Author: Rich DeVos

Quote: I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.
Author: Nathan Hale

Quote: We want great men who, when fortune frowns, will not be discouraged.
Author: Colonel Henry Knox

Quote: I don't ""get myself"" to exercise... I get to exercise!
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Confidence and creativity go hand in hand.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Success is always unfinished business.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: How many unecessary words do we clutter our speech with because we feel obligated to utter them?
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Enduring is doing...
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Problems are often messages.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: I win the rat races by not entering in them.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: True self-confidence is not thinking you're better than others. It is also not thinking that others are better than you.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Perfection is relative.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Watch what you say. Never say ""I will fail, I can't do it, I'm not good at that, etc."" Your subconscious cannot take a joke. It inevitably will bring these things to pass.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Nursing grudges is like nursing parasites of the heart.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: You must pay a price for any type of improvement. On the other hand, you will pay a price for staying just the same.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Most people are about as successful as they make up their minds to be.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: If one does not spend enough time daily maintaining order and health, he will make up for this time sooner or later by dealing with the consequences.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Other people will catch you vainly looking at your reflection as many times as you will.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: We should all have written in the fabric of our being the same thing stitched into the first American flag, which was the Latin phrase, â€œDon't tread on me.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: A rudder won't control a boat that isn't moving.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: We shouldn't just work harder, nor just work smarter; it should be both.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: To dress as a success is more important than to dress for success.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Keeping anything neat and orderly is like bailing a boat. You have to keep at it.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: We must distinguish between evaluation and judgment.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Poise and confidence come with the fact that you are prepared and you know it.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: You do no favors to those you lead by taking it easy on them.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Improve yourself to improve your circumstances.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Abstinence itself isn't good enough. Good health requires hard work.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: The first hour of the morning is the rudder of the day.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: It is neither what you know, nor who you know; it's both.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: By all means be picky, but not nitpicky.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Don't assume a door is closed; you must push on it.
Author: Marian Wright Edelman

Quote: Your abilities will seem a lot more daunting if you don't advertise them, but instead quietly, resolutely, modestly perform them.
Author: Wess Roberts

Quote: If other people's opinions are more important to you than your own, you are not in charge of your life.
Author: James R. Fisher Jr.

Quote: Failure and defeat and loss afflict us all. Expect it, learn to deal with it.
Author: Les Brown

Quote: I don't think a man can respect himself until he makes his own way.
Author: Montel Williams

Quote: Life is either a daring adventure or nothing.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: Our performance in life is a direct reflection of the image we have of ourselves.
Author: Bruce Jenner

Quote: You must never be too busy sawing to take time to sharpen the saw.
Author: Stephen R. Covey

Quote: All man's miseries derive from not being able to sit quietly in a room alone.
Author: Blaise Pascal

Quote: Whatever is flexible and flowing will tend to grow; whatever is rigid and blocked will wither and die.
Author: Lao Tzu

Quote: Laughter is the shortest distance between people.
Author: Eileen McDargh

Quote: The Platinum Rule: Treat others the way they want to be treated.
Author: Tony Alessandra

Quote: Aristocracy is all attitude.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: BE your potential.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: There are many who would rather sit and rot than break a sweat and stink.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: I believe in the power of self-affirmation; I am incredible.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Success is measured by contribution, not acquisition.
Author: William Halamandaris

Quote: At times we lament lost time as permanent defeat. But these stoppages are actually opportunities- to grow, rise, maneuver, change perspective, chart new courses. Even in that enclosure we are still moving, not forward but upward. The direction has temporarily changed; and we really should be pleased. We are being elevated to a different plane. Out of imprisonment arises a higher life.
Author: John Clements

Quote: The problem is often not the problem.
Author: Dianna Booher

Quote: We show respect by being courteous, listening attentively, and maintaining eye contact, as well as by avoiding giving advice, lecturing, and using a condescending tone.
Author: Kathy Indermill

Quote: Make all the noise about it you want, but it all still comes down to performance. Whether it's business, religion, human relations or even drag racing, the proof of your claims always shows up best in the results. Everything else is just smoke and noise. Talk is cheap. Let's see what you've got.
Author: Robert Kirby

Quote: Always keep in mind that in just about any setting, there are very few people present that are more sure of themselves than you are.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: How many things does God grant us, without having asked for them?
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: So many times, I have used calm, cool, and supreme self-confidence in place of pedigree.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: I don't pay much attention to whether people like me or not.
Author: Louis L'Amour

Quote: Loyalty brings friends.
Author: Louis L'Amour

Quote: Take care of your reputation. It's one of your most valuable assets.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: If you have a good book, you never need to be lonesome. Always, always have and keep a zest for learning. Love to learn, to be amazed at the world.
Author: Virginia G. Carlston

Quote: I challenge you to be great. To be great is to have character, integrity, and be true to noble principles.
Author: James E. Faust

Quote: Leave everything a little better than you found it. It's the only way things will get better in this world.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Miracles aren't always big ones.
Author: Lauren Bagely

Quote: Don't waste time responding to your critics.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Remember that all news is biased.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: What I love most about Emerson is the audacity he has to tackle all elements of man and lifeâ€”head on. First, he dares to confront any concept. He sizes it up, knocks it around a little, then, somehow, he takes it from the dusty pages of theory and brings it to life, giving it flesh and bones to show us how it looks in real life. He may not always be right, but I admire his audacity and clarity of thought and speech.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: I have learned that insomnia, in many cases, is the subconscious mind reminding itself that it has left certain tasks unfinished. It does not want to stop until it completes them.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: There are few things as difficult as the art of making advice agreeable.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: People are watching you. They are talking about you. They know some things about you, and guess about others. Sometimes untrue things are said about you, but there really is nothing you can do about that. We must simply hold to our own principles, conduct ourselves with dignity, and answer first to our own integrity.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Anything that makes you sweat is usually good for you, be it hard physical labor, intense exercise, or even dancing. All these things are not only good for the body, but they also cleanse our systems, strengthen the sinews, release tension, and clear the mind.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Manners are but the shine that comes off of the matter that we're made of.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Private choices are not private; they all have public consequences... Our society is the sum total of what millions of individuals do in their private lives. The sum total of private behavior has worldwide public consequences of enormous magnitude. There are no completely private choices.
Author: James E. Faust

Quote: The borrower runs in his own debt. Has a man gained any thing... by borrowing? There arises on the deed the instant acknowledgment of benefit on the one part and of debt on the other; that is, of superiority and inferiority.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Nothing venture, nothing have.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Every sweet hath its sour; every faculty which is a receiver of pleasure has an equal penalty put on its abuse.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: If you have made mistakes, even serious ones, there is always another chance for you. What we call failure is not the falling down, but the staying down.
Author: Mary Pickford

Quote: To think of losing is to lose already.
Author: Sylvia Townsend Warner

Quote: Kill the snake of doubt in your soul, crush the worms of fear in your heart and mountains will move out of your way.
Author: Kate Seredy

Quote: You do not notice changes in what is always before you.
Author: Colette

Quote: Healthy families are our greatest national resource.
Author: Dolores Curran

Quote: It is never any good dwelling on good-byes. It is no the being together that it prolongs, it is the parting.
Author: Elizabeth Bibesco

Quote: If you are being run out of town, get in front of the crowd and make it look like a parade.
Author: Sally Stanford

Quote: To fear is one thing. To let fear grab you by the tail and swing you around is another.
Author: Katherine Paterson

Quote: That fear of missing out on things makes you miss out on everything.
Author: Etty Hillesum

Quote: You can't push a wave onto the shore any faster than the ocean brings it in.
Author: Susan Strasberg

Quote: Forethought spares afterthought.
Author: Amelia E. Barr

Quote: Forgiveness is the act of admitting we are like other people.
Author: Christina Baldwin

Quote: A friend is one who withholds judgment no matter how long you have his unanswered letter.
Author: Sophie Irene Loeb

Quote: It is wise to apply the oil of refined politeness to the mechanism of friendship.
Author: Colette

Quote: Friendship is an art.
Author: Kathleen Norris

Quote: Genius is the gold in the mine, talent is the miner who works and brings it out.
Author: Lady Marguerite Blessington

Quote: You can't have genius without patience.
Author: Margaret Deland

Quote: There is nothing stronger in the world than gentleness.
Author: Han Suyin

Quote: To save the mind from preying inwardly upon itself, it must be encouraged to some outward pursuit. There is no other way to elude apathy, or escape discontent; none other to guard the temper from that quarrel with itself, which ultimately ends in quarreling with all mankind.
Author: Fanny Burney

Quote: What we truly and earnestly aspire to be, that in some sense we are. The mere aspiration, by changing the frame of the mind, for the moment realizes itself.
Author: Anna Jameson

Quote: It is almost impossible to throw dirt on someone without getting a little on yourself.
Author: Abigail Van Buren

Quote: My father used to say, ""Superior people never make long visits.
Author: Marianne Moore

Quote: Humor comes from self-confidence. There's an aggressive element to wit.
Author: Rita Mae Brown

Quote: No matter how brilliantly an idea is stated, we will not really be moved unless we have already half-thought of it ourselves.
Author: Mignon McLaughlin

Quote: Ignorance is not bliss. Ignorance is impotence; it is fear; it is cruelty; it is all the things that make for unhappiness.
Author: Winifred Holtby

Quote: It is easier to influence strong than weak characters in life.
Author: Margot Asquith

Quote: True inward quietness... is not vacancy, but stabilityâ€”the steadfastness of a single purpose.
Author: Caroline Stephen

Quote: A mistake in judgment isn't fatal, but too much anxiety about judgment is.
Author: Pauline Kael

Quote: By the time a person has achieved years adequate for choosing a direction, the die is cast and the moment has long since passed which determined the future.
Author: Zelda Fitzgerald

Quote: Where there is laughter there is always more health than sickness.
Author: Phyllis Bottome

Quote: Leisure, some degree of it, is necessary to the health of every man's spirit.
Author: Harriet Martineau

Quote: People who know how to employ themselves, always find leisure moments, while those who do nothing are forever in a hurry.
Author: Marie-Jeanne Roland

Quote: A letter is a risky thing; the writer gambles on the reader's frame of mind.
Author: Margaret Deland

Quote: Life is change: growth is optional.
Author: Karen Kaiser Clark

Quote: There is no place in the world where courtesy is so necessary as in the home.
Author: Helen Hathaway

Quote: No one would remember the Good Samaritan if he'd only had good intentions. He had money as well.
Author: Margaret Thatcher

Quote: Friends and good manners will carry you where money won't go.
Author: Margaret Walker

Quote: The likelihood of one individual being right increases in direct ratio to the intensity with which others try to prove him wrong.
Author: Leonore Fleischer

Quote: The farther behind I leave the past, the closer I am to forging my own character.
Author: Isabelle Eberhardt

Quote: I think perfectionism is based on the obsessive belief that if you run carefully enough, hitting each steppin-stone just right, you won't have to die. The truth is that you will die anyway and that a lot of people who aren't even looking at their feet are going to do a whole lot better than you, and have a lot more fun while they're doing it.
Author: Anne Lamott

Quote: Dwelling on the negative simply contributes to its power.
Author: Shirley MacLaine

Quote: All things a man owns hold him far more than he holds them.
Author: Sigrid Undset

Quote: Problems, unfortunately, can be addicting. Like it or not, we take a certain amount of pride in the very problems that distress us.
Author: Eloise Ristad

Quote: Delay breeds fear.
Author: Jessamyn West

Quote: I know how much your promises mean. Promisin talk don' cook rice.
Author: Julia Peterkin

Quote: Nothing contributes so much to tranquilize the mind as a steady purpose-a point on which the soul may fix its intellectual eye.
Author: Mary Shelley

Quote: I am in the world to change the world.
Author: Muriel Rukeyser

Quote: The only questions that really matter are the ones you ask yourself.
Author: Ursula K. Le Guin

Quote: The power to question is the basis of all human progress.
Author: Indira Gandhi

Quote: The more you kick something that's dead, the worse it smells.
Author: Barbara Stanwyck

Quote: The bitterest tears shed over graves are for words left unsaid and deeds left undone.
Author: Christopher Crowfield

Quote: We must be careful what we say. No bird resumes its egg.
Author: Emily Dickinson

Quote: Everybody must learn this lesson somewhere-that it costs something to be what you are.
Author: Shirley Abbott

Quote: One can never consent to creep when one feels an impulse to soar.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: When I'm trusting and being myself as fully possible, everything in my life reflects this by falling into place easily, often miraculously.
Author: Shakti Gawain

Quote: The world never puts a price on you higher than the one you put on yourself.
Author: Sonja Henie

Quote: Get rid of the tendency to judge yourself above, below, or equal to others.
Author: Abhirupa-Nanda

Quote: No star is ever lost we once have seen. We always may be what we might have been.
Author: Adelaide Anne Procter

Quote: To be criticised is not necessarily to be wrong.
Author: Sir Anthony Eden

Quote: To the victor belongs the toils.
Author: Adlai Stevenson

Quote: The Peter Principle: In a hierarchy every employee tends to rise to his level of incompetence.
Author: Lawrence J. Peter

Quote: The things that a man does not say often reveal the understanding and penetration of his mind even more than the things he says.
Author: Robert A. Milikan

Quote: Of course, sometimes it is not possible to prepare an address fully, but it is much better to do so even if you intend to speak extemporaneously.
Author: Robert A. Taft

Quote: Happiness is beneficial for the body but it is grief that develops the powers of the mind.
Author: Marcel Proust

Quote: Anyone who can read and who owns a dictionary can become an educated person. Hungry minds always become educated and sharpen their mental and emotional tools as they grow in life through experience.
Author: Galen Starr Ross

Quote: People don't ask for facts in making up their minds. They would rather have one good, soul-satisfying emotion than a dozen facts.
Author: Robert Keith Levitt

Quote: Never open the door to a little vice lest a great one enter with it.
Author: proverb

Quote: Those who really thirst for knowledge always get it.
Author: proverb

Quote: A good husband makes a good wife.
Author: proverb

Quote: Every heart hath its own ache.
Author: proverb

Quote: It is the heart which makes men eloquent.
Author: Latin proverb

Quote: One of these days is none of these days.
Author: proverb

Quote: He gives twice who gives quickly.
Author: Latin proverb

Quote: Boldness has genius, power, and magic in it.
Author: Goethe

Quote: Make sure of the bear before you sell his skin.
Author: Aesop

Quote: Hazard not your wealth on a poor man's advice.
Author: Spanish proverb

Quote: Laziness grows on people; it begins in cobwebs and ends in iron chains. The more business a man has to do the more he is able to accomplish, for he learns to economize his time.
Author: Sir M. Hale

Quote: A well-cultivated mind is made up of all the minds of preceding ages.
Author: Fontenelle

Quote: Judge of a man by his questions rather than by his answers.
Author: Voltaire

Quote: They only babble who practice not reflection. I shall think; and thought is silence.
Author: Sheridan

Quote: A truly wise man should have no keeper of his secret but himself.
Author: Guizot

Quote: To have what we want is riches, but to be able to do without is power.
Author: G. Macdonald

Quote: My riches consist not in the extent of my possessions, but in the fewness of my wants.
Author: J. Brotherton

Quote: In taking revenge a man is but equal to his enemy, but in passing it over he is his superior.
Author: Bacon

Quote: The way to gain a good reputation, is, to endeavor to be what you desire to appear.
Author: Socrates

Quote: Apt to promise is apt to forget.
Author: Thomas Fuller

Quote: A polite man is one who listens with interest to things he knows all about, when they are told him by a person who knows nothing about them.
Author: De Morny

Quote: The generous heart should scorn a pleasure which give others pain.
Author: Thomson

Quote: It is only imperfection that complains of what is imperfect. The more perfect we are, the more gentle and quiet we become toward the defects of others.
Author: Fenelon

Quote: Steady, patient, persevering thinking will generally surmount every obstacle in the search after truth.
Author: Emmons

Quote: Patience is bitter, but its fruit is sweet.
Author: Rousseau

Quote: Little minds are tamed and subdued by misfortune; but great minds rise above it.
Author: Washington Irving

Quote: The true art of memory is the art of attention.
Author: Johnson

Quote: It takes a clever man to turn cynic and a wise man to be clever enough not to.
Author: Fannie Hurst

Quote: He that is good for making excuses, is seldom good for anything else.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: Luxury makes a man so soft, that it is hard to please him, and easy to trouble him; so that his pleasures at last become his burden. Luxury is a nice master, hard to be pleased.
Author: Mackenzie

Quote: To be rich in admiration and free from envy; to rejoice greatly in the good of others; to love with such generosity of heart that your love is still a dear possession in absence or unkindnessâ€”these are the gifts of fortune which money cannot buy and without which money can buy nothing. He who has such a treasury of riches, being happy and valiant himself, in his own nature, will enjoy the universe as if it were his own estate; and help the man to whom he lends a hand to enjoy it with him.
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson

Quote: The more we study the more we discover our ignorance.
Author: Shelley

Quote: Thou mayest be sure that he that will in private tell thee of thy faults, is thy friend, for he adventures thy dislike, and doth hazard thy hatred; there are few men that can endure it, every man for the most part delighting in self-praise, which is one of the most universal follies that bewitchedth mankind.
Author: Sir Walter Raleigh

Quote: A simple fact that is difficult to learn is that the time to save money is when you have some.
Author: Unknown

Quote: A person needs at intervals to separate himself from family and companions and go to new places. He must go without his familiars in order to be open to influences, to change.
Author: Katharine Butler Hathaway

Quote: It is wise to be sure, but otherwise to be too sure.
Author: Sophi Irene Loeb

Quote: Like water which can clearly mirror the sky and the trees only so long as its surface is undisturbed, the mind can only reflect the true image of the self when it is tranquil and wholly relaxed.
Author: Indra Devi

Quote: The fresh start is always an illusion but a necessary one.
Author: Eleanor Clark

Quote: The appetite grows for what it feeds on.
Author: Ida B. Wells

Quote: Why is life speeded up so? Why are things so terribly, unbearably precious that you can't enjoy them but can only wait breathless in dread of their going?
Author: Anne Morrow Lindbergh

Quote: T'ain't worthwhile to wear a day all out before it comes.
Author: Sarah Orne Jewett

Quote: People who feel their character to be slight, hope to give it weight by inflation: but the blown bladder at its fullest distention is still empty.
Author: Hannah More

Quote: Ambition is peculiarly the passion of great minds. It is the aspiration after a sphere of those who feel within them the capability of filling one.
Author: Lady Wilde

Quote: The true secret of giving advice is, after you have honestly given it, to be perfectly indifferent whether it is taken or not, and never persist in trying to set people right.
Author: Hannah Whitall Smith

Quote: It is not advisable to venture unsolicited opinions. You should spare yourself the embarrassing discovery of their exact value to your listener.
Author: Ayn Rand

Quote: There can be no happiness if the things we believe in are different from the things we do.
Author: Freya Stark

Quote: I have long since come to believe that people never mean half of what they say, and that it is best to disregard their talk and judge only their actions.
Author: Dorothy Day

Quote: I think one's feelings waste themselves in words; they ought all to be distilled into actions which bring results.
Author: Florence Nightingale

Quote: It is better to wear out than to rust out
Author: Frances E. Willard

Quote: Abundance is, in large part, an attitude.
Author: Sue Patton Thoele

Quote: From the first day in school until the day I graduated, everyone gave me one hundred plus in art. Well, where do you go in life? You go to the place where you got one hundred plus.
Author: Louse Nevelson

Quote: A good character will be soiled at least by frequent contact with a bad one.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Prepare and digest your matter well in your own thoughts, and the words not unwilling will follow.
Author: Horace

Quote: Cheerfulness and good nature are the effects of virtue.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Discretion will carry a man of moderate parts farther than the most shining parts would without it.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: In conversing with those who are much your superiors, however easy and familiar you may and ought to be with them, preserve the respect that is due to them.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Do not preach and moralize in a company full of mirth and gaiety.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Attend carefully in the first place to human nature in general, which is pretty much the same in all human creatures. Analyse, anatomise it. Carefully observe the words, the looks, and gestures of the company you are in, and retain all their little singularities, humors, tastes, antipathies and affections.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Let a young man persevere with a becoming modesty, and he will find that all people of good nature will assist and help him out.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Have a cool intrepid assurance with great seeming modesty.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: One is worth in this world only what one wishes to be worth.
Author: Bruyere

Quote: If you have real wit it will flow spontaneously and you need not aim at it.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Endeavor to be cool and steady upon all occasions. The advantages of such a steady calmness are innumerable... It may be acquired by care and reflection.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: When your opinion differs from others, maintain it only with modesty, calmness, and gentleness, but never be eager, loud, and clamourous, and when you find your antagonist beginning to grow warm, put an end to the debate by some gentle way.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Let your address when you first come into any company be modest, but without the least bashfulness or sheepishness, steady without impudence, and as unembarrassed as if you were alone in your own room.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Let us not only scatter benefits, but even strew flowers for our fellow-travelers, in the rugged ways of this wretched world.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Remember in steep affairs to keep a level head. (Horace) Be neither transported nor depressed by the accidents of life.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Though we cannot totally change our nature, we may in a great measure correct it, by reflection and philosophy.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: No young man can possibly improve in any company for which he has not respect enough to be under some degree of restraint.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: We are all made of the same clay, though some of the lumps are a little finer, and some a little coarser; but, in general, the surest way to judge of others is to examine and analyse one's self thoroughly.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Gently in manner, boldly in action... This precept is the only way I know in the world of being loved without being despised, and feared without being hated. It constitutes the dignity of character, which every wise man must endeavour to establish.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: You must take care to be extremely well dressed. This does by no means consist in the finery, but in the taste, fitness, and manner of wearing your clothes.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: It is by being well dressed, not finely dressed, that a gentleman should be distinguished.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Connections are absolutely necessary; and, if prudently formed, and ably maintained, the success of them is infallible.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Have no pleasures but your own, and then you will shine in them.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Be, and be reckoned a man of pleasure, as well as a man of business. Enjoy life; shine in the pleasures, and the company of people.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Had I really seen anything so very extraordinary as to be almost incredible, I would keep it to myself, rather than, by telling it, give anybody room to doubt for one minute of my veracity.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: There is nothing so delicate as your moral character, and nothing which it is your interest so much to preserve pure.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Reserves and cautions are very necessary to have, but very imprudent to show.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Be upon your guard against those, who, upon very slight acquaintance, obtrude their unasked and unmerited friendship and confidence upon you; for they probably cram you with them only for their own eating: but, at the same time, do not roughly reject them upon that general supposition. Examine further, and see whether those unexpected offers flow from a warm heart and a silly head, or from a designing head and a cold heart.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: A man's general character may be that of the most honest man of the world: do not dispute it; you might be thought envious or ill-natured; but, at the same time, do not take this soley upon trust, to such a degree as to put your life, fortune, or reputation in his power. This honest man many happen to be your rival in power, in interest, or in love; three passions that often put honesty to most severe trials.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Though men are all of one composition, the several ingredients are so differently proportioned in each individual, that no two are exactly alike; and no one at all times like himself... Study individuals then.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: With all the knowledge which you may have at present, or hereafter acquire, if you have not a good degree of eloquence in speaking and writing, you will be nobody; but will have the daily mortification of seeing people, with not one-tenth part of your merit or knowledge, get the start of you.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Gain the heart or you gain nothing; the eyes and ears are the only roads to the heart. Merit and knowledge will not gain hearts, though they will secure them when gained.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Constant experience has shown me, that great purity and elegance of style, with a graceful elocution, cover a multitude of faults, in either a speaker or a writer.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The most familiar and intimate relationships, connections, and friendships, require a degree of good manners, both to preserve and cement them. If ever a man and his wife absolutely lay aside all manners, their intimacy will soon degenerate into a coarse familiarity.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: I am convinced that education, more than nature, is the cause of that great difference which you see in the characters of men.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Noble and easy manners are as necessary to adorn and introduce your intrinsic merit and knowledge as the polish is to the diamond; which, without that polish, would never be worn, whatever it might weigh.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: A vulgar, ordinary way of acting or speaking implies a low education, and a habit of low company.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The shortest, civil answers are the best.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Whoever is in a hurry, shows that the thing he is about is too big for him. Haste and hurry are very different things.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The temptation of saying a smart and witty thing has made people more enemies than any other thing that I know of. Jokes, waggery, and indiscriminate familiarity will sink both merit and knowledge into a degree of contempt. Indiscriminate familiarity either offends your superiors, or else dubs you their dependent, and led captain. It gives your inferiors just, but troublesome and improper claims of equality.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Make yourself absolute master of your temper and your countenanceâ€”so far, at least, as that no visible change do appear in either, whatever you may feel inwardly.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: A man who does not possess himself enough to hear disagreeable things without visible marks of anger and change of countenance, or agreeable ones without sudden bursts of joy and expansion of countenance, is at the mercy of every artful knave.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: I recommend to you an innocent piece of artâ€”flatter people behind their backs, in presence of those who will not fail to repeat, and even amplify, the praise to the party concerned. This is, of all flattery, the most pleasing, and consequently the most effectual.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: In order to know people's real sentiments, I trust much more to my eyes than to my ears; for they can say whatever they have a mind I should hear; but they can seldom help looking what they have no intention that I should know.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The height of abilities is to have a frank, open, and ingenious exterior, with a prudent and reserved interior; to be upon your own guard, and yet, by a seeming natural openness, put people off theirs.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: He who addresses himself singly to another man's reason, without endeavoring to engage his heart in his interest also, is [not likely to succeed.]
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The character of a well-bred man is, to converse with his inferiors without insolence, and with his superiors with trifles and with ease.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: I am convinced, that a light supper, a good night's sleep, and a fine morning, have sometimes made a hero of the same man, who by an indigestion, a restless night, and a rainy morning, would have proved a coward.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: From your own observation, reflect what a disagreeable impression an ungraceful manner of speaking, a slovenly figure, etc., make upon you, at first sight, in a stranger, and how they prejudice you against him, though, for aught you know, he may have great intrinsic sense and merit.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The mind is often the dupe of the heart. (Rochefoucauld) This being the case, aim at the heart. Intrinsic merit alone will not do; it will gain you the general esteem of all; but not the particular affection, that is, the heart of any.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Speak the language of the company you are in.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Some learned men, proud of their knowledge, only speak to decide, and give judgment without appeal... The more you know, the modester you should be; and that modesty is the surest way of gratifying your vanity. Even when you are sure, seem rather doubtful; represent, but do not pronounce; and if you would convince others, seem open to conviction yourself.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: There is hardly any place, or any company, where you may not gain knowledge; almost everybody knows some one thing, and is glad to talk about that one thing.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Whatever you do, do it to the purpose; do it thoroughly, not superficially. Go to the bottom of things. Anything half done, or half-known, is neither done nor known at all.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: What I do, and ever shall, regret, is the time which I lost in mere idleness, and in doing nothing.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Whoever knows virtue must love it. As for knowledge, those who have the most are always the most desirous to have more, and know that the most they can have is, alas! but too little.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Accustom yourself to write down the capital points of what you learn.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Merit and good manners will make their way everywhere. Knowledge will introduce him, and good manners will endear him to the best companies; for politeness and good manners are absolutely necessary to adorn any, or all other good qualities or talents.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: You may ask me, whether a man has it always in his power to get into the best company? and how? I say, Yes, he has, by deserving it.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: People will, in a great degree, and not without reason, form their opinion of you, upon that which they have of your friends.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Remember to make a great difference between companions and friends; for a very complaisant and agreeable companion may, and often does, prove a very improper and dangerous friend.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Were I to begin the world again, with the experience which I now have of it, I would lead a life of real, not of imaginary, pleasure.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Choose your pleasures for yourself, and do not let them be imposed upon you. Follow nature, and not fashion; weigh the present enjoyment of your pleasures against the necessary consequences of them, and then let your own common sense determine you choice.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Pleasure is the rock which most young people split upon.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Do not flatter yourself with the thought that you can acquire knowledge of mankind in the frivolous chit-chat of idle companies; no, you must go much deeper than that. You must look into people, as well as at them.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: To know mankind well, requires full as much attention and application as to know books, and it may be, more sagacity and discernment.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The knowledge of the world is only to be acquired in the world, and not in a closet.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Knowledge of the world is still more necessary than that of books. In truth, they assist one another reciprocally; and no man will have either perfectly, who has not both.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Studies nourish youth, delight old age, adorn prosperity, offer a refuge and a comfort for adversity, charm us at home, do not hamper us abroad, spend the night with us, go with us to foreign parts, stay with us in the country.
Author: Cicero

Quote: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing; drink deep, or taste not the Castalian spring.
Author: Alexander Pope

Quote: You must read men as well as books.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Be wiser than other people if you can; but do not tell them so.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Dress is a very foolish thing; and yet it is a very foolish thing for a man not to be well dressed.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Without attention nothing is to be done. You should not only have attention to everything, but a quickness of attention, so as to observe, at once, all the people in the room; their motions, their looks, and their words; and yet without staring at them, and seeming to be an observer. This quick and unobserved observation is of infinite advantage in life, and is to be acquired with care.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: There is an awkwardness of expression and words most carefully to be avoided; such as bad pronunciation, old sayings, and common proverbs; which are many proofs of having kept bad and low company.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Remember, then, that to be civil, and to be civil with ease (which is properly called good-breeding), is the only way to be beloved and well received in company; and that to be bashful is to be ridiculous.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Whenever you are commended for anything, consider fairly, with yourself, whether you deserve it or not; and if you do not deserve it, remember that you are only abused and laughed at; and endeavor to deserve better for the future, and to prevent the irony.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The gentleman will not only make his own manners impeccable but keep his own passions well under control.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Travel is a component of education when seriously undertaken.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The learning found in books should be augmented by a knowledge of the world itself; the thoroughness of the scholar should not degenerate into pedantry or preoccupation with details.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: The man of honour speaks the truth and keeps his word, but duelling is the recourse of the mistaken gentleman who insists on a ""point of honour.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Letters should be easy and natural, and convey to the persons to whom we send them, just what we would say to those persons, if we were with them.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: It is a poor recommendation to be a well-bred gentleman without being an honest man, but an honest man if disagreeable will forfeit the benefits of honesty.
Author: Chesterfield

Quote: Ninety-nine days the word of the preacher should be buoyant and of good cheer, so that on the hundredth day the voice of censure may be a hundred times strong. This was Lincoln's way.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: Optimism is the faith that leads to achievement; nothing can be done without hope.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: Pessimism kills the instinct that urges men to struggle.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: I consider it a duty to myself and to others to be happy.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: The test of all beliefs is their practical effect in life.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: How pitiable is the cramped sense of imprisonment in circumstances which teaches men to expect no good and to treat any attempt to relieve them as the vagary of a disordered mind!
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: Deep, solemn optimism, it seems to me, should spring from this firm belief in the presence of God in the individual; not a remote, unapproachable governor of the universe, but a God who is very near every one of us.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: I long to accomplish a great and noble task; but it is my chief duty and joy to accomplish humble tasks as though they were great and noble.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: The Ideal is in thyself; the impediment is also in thyself. Work on the Ideal in the poor, miserable Actual; live, think, believe, and be free!
Author: Thomas Carlyle

Quote: The world is sown with good; but unless I turn my glad thoughts into practical living and till my own field, I cannot reap a kernel of the good.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: Optimism that does not count the cost is like a house built on sand. A man must understand evil and be acquainted with sorrow before he can write himself an optimist and expect others to believe that he has reason for the faith that is in him.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: It is a mistake always to contemplate the good and ignore the evil... There is a dangerous optimism of ignorance and indifference.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: If I am happy in spite of my deprivations, if my happiness is so deep that it is a faith, so thoughtful that it becomes a philosophy of life, -if, in short, I am an optimist, my testimony to the creed of optimism is worth hearing.
Author: Helen Keller

Quote: The art of living rightly is like all arts; it must be learned and practiced with incessant care.
Author: Goethe

Quote: Every great man is always being helped by everybody; for his gift is to get good out of all things and people.
Author: Ruskin

Quote: A prudent person profits from personal experience, a wise one from the experience of others.
Author: Joseph Collins

Quote: WHY and HOW are words so important that they cannot be too often used.
Author: Napolean

Quote: When a man has equipped himself by thought and study for a bigger job, it usually happens that promotion comes along even before it's expected.
Author: P.G. Winnett

Quote: Never shrink from doing anything which your business calls you to do. The man who is above his business may one day find his business above him.
Author: Drew

Quote: A duty dodged is like a debt unpaid; it is only deferred, and we must come back and settle the account at last.
Author: Joseph Newton

Quote: It is not half as important to burn the midnight oil as it is to be awake in the daytime.
Author: E.W. Elmore

Quote: That which grows slowly endures.
Author: J.G. Holland

Quote: Let a man try faithfully, manfully to be right, he will daily grow more and more right. It is at the bottom of the condition on which all men have to cultivate themselves.
Author: Carlyle

Quote: Without consistency there is no moral strength.
Author: Owen

Quote: Men must be taught as if you taught them not; and things unknown proposed as things forgot.
Author: Alexander Pope

Quote: A sentence is enough for a sensible man.
Author: Plautus

Quote: A man should always have his boots on, and be ready to go.
Author: Montaigne

Quote: Oft-times nothing profits more than self-esteem, grounded on just and right well managed.
Author: Milton

Quote: I bend and I break not.
Author: La Fontaine

Quote: The art of being wise is the art of knowing what to overlook.
Author: William James

Quote: He that repeateth a matter separateth very friends.
Author: Proverbs 17:9

Quote: Avoid witticisms at the expense of others.
Author: Horace Mann

Quote: One hour's sleep before midnight is worth three after.
Author: George Herbert

Quote: The sleep of the laboring man is sweet.
Author: Ecclesiastes 5:12

Quote: Prevention is better than cure.
Author: Erasmus

Quote: No man should part with his own individuality and become that of another.
Author: Channing

Quote: Neat, not gaudy.
Author: Lamb

Quote: Refuse to be ill. Never tell people you are ill; never own it to yourself... man should resist it on principle on the outset.
Author: Bulwer-Lyton

Quote: Propriety of manners and consideration for others are the two main characteristics of a gentleman.
Author: Disraeli

Quote: No man can be provident of his time who is not prudent in the choice of his company.
Author: Jeremy Taylor

Quote: He that walketh with wise men shall be wise.
Author: Proverbs 13:20

Quote: Never answer a letter while you are angry.
Author: Chinese proverb

Quote: Never give advice unless asked.
Author: German proverb

Quote: He that is overcautious will accomplish little.
Author: Schiller

Quote: Being unable to direct events, I govern myself.
Author: Montaigne

Quote: Some people drink at the fountain of knowledge; others just gargle.
Author: Author Unknown

Quote: Have a real reserve with everybody and a seeming reserve with almost nobody; for it is very disagreeable to seem reserved but dangerous not to be so.
Author: Lord Chesterfield

Quote: Polished, not slick. There's a world of difference.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Flattery is like cologne water, to be smelt of, not swallowed.
Author: Billings

Quote: Get someone else to blow your horn and the sound will carry twice as far.
Author: Will Rogers

Quote: He who praises everybody, praises nobody.
Author: Samuel Johnson

Quote: Stillness of person and steadiness of features are signal marks of good breeding.
Author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

Quote: An inability to stay quiet is one of the conspicuous failings of mankind.
Author: Walter Bagehot

Quote: Think like a man of action, and act like a man of thought.
Author: Henri Bergson

Quote: The actions of men are the best interpreters of their thoughts.
Author: Locke

Quote: My father always told me, â€œIf you want to play, make it impossible for the coach to keep you off the field.
Author: Wayne Alan Carlston

Quote: Nothing so augments appeal as that of being unavailable.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: The very essence of all power to influence lies in getting the other person to participate. The mind that can do that has a powerful leverage on his human world.
Author: Harry Overstreet

Quote: My suggestion to ambitious young men would be to conserve and develop their physical and mental strength, cram their heads with all the useful knowledge they can, and work, work, work- not simply for their own advancement but to get worthwhile things done.
Author: Edward Seubert

Quote: Not failure, but low aim, is a crime.
Author: Ernest Holmes

Quote: The mind is like the stomach. It is not how much you put into it that counts, but how much it digests.
Author: A.J. Noek

Quote: We must make automatic habitual, as early as possible, as many useful actions as we can. The more of the details of our daily life we can hand over to the effortless custody of automatism, the more our higher powers of mind will be set free for their own proper work.
Author: William James

Quote: When, against one's will, one is high pressured into making a hurried decision, the best answer is always ""NO"" because ""NO"" is more easily changed to ""yes"" than to ""yes"" to ""no.
Author: Charles Nielson

Quote: We are most apt to criticize others when we see our own faults in them.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: I've always felt that it is better for people to not see enough of you than to see too much of you.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Don't be vain. People catch you looking at your reflection as many times as you do.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Sometimes you need to ask yourself if you know the answer already, before you ask a question. Then ask yourself the consequences of asking that question.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Before you enter any room, always check yourself, and enter with purpose and confidence.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: We may seek the acclaim (praise, recognition and status) others can give us. If we get our validationâ€”our feelings of self-worthâ€”from the way others treat us, we become controlled by other' opinion of us. In so doing, we lose sight of our original goals. We become externally controlled, and others-sensing our shift in focus-stop trusting our intentions, motives and actions.
Author: Stephen Covey

Quote: Our father didnâ€™t try too hard to talk to usâ€”thus he didnâ€™t have to try. The less he made us listen to him, the more we listened. Also, because he didnâ€™t counsel us on the trivial things unneccessarily, we viewed his counsel on the important things as necessary.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: When you're unhappy, or distressed, or even miserable, many times the cause is not what you think it is. Rather, something in your personal life is off balance, in excess or lack thereof.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: It is where a man spends his money that shows where his heart lies.
Author: A. Edwin Kiegin

Quote: A true man never frets about his place in the world, but just slides into it by the gravitation of his nature, and stays like a star.
Author: E.H. Chapin

Quote:
Recipe for Success:
 Be polite, prepare yourself for whatever you are asked to do, keep yourself tidy, be cheerful, don't be envious, be honest with yourself so you will be honest with others, be helpful, interest yourself in your job, don't pity yourself, be quick to praise, be loyal to your friends, avoid prejudices, be independent, interest yourself in politics, and read the newspapers.
Author: Baruch

Quote: Class, distinction, dignity and grace are not inherited traits. One must live them, and cultivate them, and any person can. I may not be able to afford the nicest clothing, but that does not mean I will not be clean and classy. I may not be able to afford an elite educational experience, but most reading does not cost me. Excellence, quality, and success come from the inside-out.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: The true gentleman is solid mahogany: the fashionable man is only veneer.
Author: J.G. Holland

Quote: There are times when God asks nothing of his children except silence, patience and tears.
Author: CS Robinson

Quote: Be sincere. Be simple in words, manners, and gestures. Amuse as well as instruct. If you can make a man laugh, you can make him think and make him like and believe you.
Author: Alfred Smith

Quote: Sincerity is impossible unless it pervades the whole being, and the pretense of it saps the very foundation of character.
Author: James Lowell

Quote: There is no business, avocation, whatever, which will not permit a man, who has the inclination, to give a little time, every day, to study.
Author: Daniel Wyttenbach

Quote: Tact is the unsaid part of what you think; its opposite, the unthought part which you say.
Author: Henry Van Dyke

Quote: A quiet conscience makes one so serene.
Author: Byron

Quote: Let us keep our mouths shut and our pens dry until we know the facts.
Author: A.J. Carlson

Quote: Discreetly keep most of your radical opinions to yourself. When with people be a listener a large part of the time. Be considerate in every word and act, and resist the tendency to say clever things. The best evidence of your culture is the tone and temper of your conversation.
Author: Grenville Kleiser

Quote: A man cannot utter two or three sentences without disclosing to intelligent ears precisely where he stands in life and thought, whether in the kingdom of the senses and the understanding, or in that of ideas and imagination, or in the realms of intuitions and duty.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: All the strength and force of man comes from his faith in things unseen. He who believes is strong; he who doubts is weak. Strong convictions precede great actions.
Author: J.F. Clarke

Quote: In the world and at home, you have the opportunity and the responsibility to help make the choices which will determine the greatness of this nation... You live in the most privileged nation on earth. You are the most privileged citizens of that nation; for you have been given the opportunity to study and learn... You can use your enormous privilege and opportunity to seek purely private pleasure and gain. But history will judge you, and as the years pass, you will ultimately judge yourself, on the extent to which you have used your gifts to lighten and enrich the lives of your fellow man. In your hands, not with presidents or leaders, is the future of your world and the fulfillment of the best qualities of your own spirit.
Author: Robert F. Kennedy

Quote: It's easy for a boss to awe his clerks, but a man who is feared to his face is hated behind his back. A competent boss can move among his men without having to draw an imaginary line between them, because they will see the real one if it exists.
Author: George Lorimer

Quote: Never learn anything about your men except from themselves... The phonograph records of a fellow's character are lined in his face, and a man's days tell the secrets of his nights.
Author: George Lorimer

Quote: Consider carefully before you say a hard word to a man, but never let a chance to say a good one go by. Praise judiciously bestowed is money invested.
Author: George Lorimer

Quote: No man can ask more than he gives. A fellow who can't take orders can't give them.
Author: George Lorimer

Quote: But ah! think what you do when you run in debt; you give to another power over your liberty.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: If the individual's wants are to be urgent they must be original with himself. They cannot be urgent if they must be contrived for him.
Author: John Kenneth Galbraith

Quote: A standard of living is of the nature of habit. It is a habitual scale and method of responding to given stimuli. The difficulty in the way of receding from an accustomed standard is the difficulty of breaking a habit that has once been formed.
Author: Thorstein Veblen

Quote: The art of living is to be engaged in the money game without being devoured by it.
Author: Jacob Needleman

Quote: Let me give you a tip on a clue to men's characters: the man who damns money has obtained it dishonorably; the man who respects it has earned it.
Author: Ayn Rand

Quote: Money will not purchase happiness for the man who has no concept of what he wants: Money will not give hint a code of values, if he's evaded the knowledge of what to value, and it will not provide him with a purpose, if he's evaded the choice of what to seek. Money will not buy intelligence for the fool, or admiration for the coward or respect for the incompetent.
Author: Ayn Rand

Quote: People, for the most part, rarely like to feel like they are being treated differently for any ulterior motive, and whether it be an active awareness or a subconscious feeling, they tend to have the opposite reaction that is desired by the person trying to impress them.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Want is a growing giant whom the coat of Have was never large enough to cover.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: The secret of success lies never in the amount of money, but in the relation of income to outgo; as, after expense has been fixed at a certain point, then new and steady rills of income, though never so small, being added, wealth begins.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Men of sense esteem wealth to be the assimilation of nature to themselves, the conveying of the sap and juices of the planet to the incarnation and nutriment of their design. Power is what they want, not candy- power to execute their design, power to give legs and feet form and actuality to their thought.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Let us settle ourselves, and work and wedge our feet downward through the mud and slush of opinion, and prejudce, and tradition, and delusion, and appearance, that alluvion which covers the globe, till we come to a hard bottom and rocks in place, which we can call reality, and say, This is, and no mistake...
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: Most of the luxuries, and many of the so-called comforts of life, are not only not indispensable, but positive hindrances to the elevation of mankind.
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: As if you could kill time without injuring eternity.
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: Men sometimes speak as if the study of the classics would at length make way for more modern and practical studies; but the adventurous student will always study classics. For what are the classics but the noblest recorded thoughts of man?
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: There is a great difference between an overstuffed brain and the inquiring, well-exercised intellect that is a mark of most gentlemen.
Author: Peter Mayle

Quote: The sad fact is that there are many people who are deliberately, consistently unpunctual. In some cases, they act this way to remind themselves and their underlings how fabulously important they are. Occasionally, such incidents are merely the result of chronically bad personal organization; more often they reveal an offensive disregard for other people's time. A failure to be on time displays an insulting lack of consideration for those who have to wait. And consideration for others is the hallmark of the true gent.
Author: Peter Mayle

Quote: Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire.
Author: William Butler Yeats

Quote: Focusing your efforts on creating a new perception is more effective than trying to undo a current one.
Author: Kim Krisco

Quote: The thick atmosphere of the rat race accelerates the burning up of the self; and this is against nature. There's no point burning your existential candle at both ends when it merely casts a sickly light into your own life and no light at all into anyone else's.
Author: John Clements

Quote: You can't escape it: if you are ""out there,"" you will encounter critics.
Author: Patricia Fripp

Quote: The master measures his servants not by the number of hours given, but what the worker has become within.
Author: Dallin H. Oaks

Quote: Every person who lives in this world wields an influence whether for good or for evil. It is not what he says alone; it is not alone what he does. It is what he is. Every person radiates what he or she really is. Every person is a recipient of radiation. The Saviour was conscious of that. Whenever He came into the presence of an individual... He was conscious of the radiation of the individual. And to a degree so are you, and so am I. It is what we are and what we radiate that affects the people around us.
Author: David O. Mackay

Quote: We read books to find out who we are. What other people, real or imaginary, do and think and feel is an essential guide to our understanding of what we ourselves are and may become.
Author: Ursula K. LeGuin

Quote: Good habits are not made on birthday, nor a Christian character at the new year. The workshop of character is everyday life. The uneventful and commonplace hour is where the battle is lost or won.
Author: Maltie D. Babcock

Quote: Some are tested by poor health, some by a body that is deformed or homely. Others are tested by handsome bodies; some by the passion of youth; others by the erosion of old age. Some suffer disappoinment in marriage, family problems, others live in poverty and obscurity. Some (perhaps this is the hardest test) find ease and luxury. All are a part of the test and there is more equality in this test than we sometimes suspect.
Author: Boyd K. Packer

Quote: That which we persist in doing becomes easier to do; not that the nature of the thing is changed, but our power to do is increased.
Author: Heber J. Grant

Quote: Work is not always required... There is such a thing as sacred idleness, the cultivation of which is now fearfully neglected.
Author: George Macdonald

Quote: We shape our dwellings, and afterwards our dwellings shape us.
Author: Winston Churchill

Quote: Whatever you can do or dream you can, begin it; boldness has genius, power and magic in it.
Author: Goethe

Quote: Always be a first-rate version of yourself, instead of a second-rate version of somebody else.
Author: Judy Garland

Quote: Those who contemplate the beauty of the earth find reserves of strength that will endure as long as life lasts. There is something infinitely healing in the repeated refrains of nature-the assurance that dawn comes after night and spring after winter.
Author: Rachel Carson

Quote: The most beautiful discovery true friends make is that they can grow separately without growing apart.
Author: Elisabeth Foley

Quote: Our own faults seen in others are those that we most quickly point out.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: Those things that we call extraordinary, remarkable, or unusual may make history, but they do not make real life. To be a successful father or mother is greater than to be a successful general or statesman.
Author: Howard W. Hunter

Quote: What man wants is not talent, it is purpose; not power to achieve, but the will to labor.
Author: Lord Bulwer Lyton

Quote: Too many people allow inertia and other peopleâ€™s choices to shape their own lives. We need to live deliberately, proactively, and consciously, realizing that most of the time, it is our move.
Author: David Alan Carlston

Quote: All the really good ideas I ever had came to me while I was milking a cow.
Author: Grant Wood

Quote: It raises one above the herd and gives one a feeling of nobility and exultation to admit one's mistakes.
Author: Dale Carnegie

Quote: I judge people by their own principles - not by my own.
Author: Martin Luther King

Quote: I have found it of enormous value when I can permit myself to understand the other person... Our first reaction is to most of the statements which we hear from other people is an evaluation or judgment, rather than an understanding of it. When someone expresses some feeling, attitude or belief, our tendency is almost immediately to feel ""that's right,"" or ""that's stupid,"" ""that's abnormal,"" ""that's unreasonable,"" ""that's incorrect,"" ""that's not nice."" Very rarely do we permit ourselves to understand precisely what the meaning of the statement is to the other person.
Author: Carl Rogers

Quote: Better to be a strong man with a weak point, than to be a weak man without a strong point. A diamond with a flaw is more valuable than a brick without a flaw.
Author: Wm. J. H. Boetcker

Quote: Five minutes, just before going to sleep, given to a bit of directed imagination regarding achievement possibilities of the morrow, will steadily and increasingly bear fruit, particularly if all ideas of difficulty, worry or fear are resolutely ruled out and replaced by those of accomplishment and smiling courage.
